comments.commentBody:
BJ, FIVE WS tripped me up, too, since I wrote in FOUR WS!

Four Freedoms, Five W's!

(FYI, "nanny cams" are for parents wanting to make sure the nanny isn't sitting eating bon-bons while Junior's in the kitchen opening the knife drawer.)
Or that the nanny isn't mistreating Junior behind the parents' backs.

Interesting theme. Didn't fully get it until coming to the blog, but I sure enjoyed the puzzle. New for me was litotes, the term. Also FIVE WS tripped me up a bit although I managed to see SO I SEE before too long. There are NANNY CAMs? Whoa! Loved THICK AS A BRICK and was particularly happy to have remembered UTHER Pendragon; those King Arthur novels scored!

On one side we have Americans who defend the rights of anyone to own and carry a deadly weapon wherever they please. On the other side we have law enforcement taking a shoot first attitude whenever they suspect that the individual is holding a deadly weapon. Compound the problem with the fact that the police forces look a lot more like occupation troops complete with field camouflage and military weapons and act like they are at war with the civilians. What are our priorities when it comes to deadly weapons and their look-alike toy versions? Until we can resolve this there will be more-and-more senseless deaths.

Strange, I don't hear that the NRA is defending the rights of children to have look-alike toys while defending the rights of others to carry the real thing.
Imagine a society where everyone carries a gun. How do you keep from getting shot when you are surrounded by people with guns? You shoot them before they shoot you. Thanks NRA, we're almost there.
Hammad Aslam you are right many Americans don't know the ground realities in Pakistan and we are insensitive and reckless with the words we use, particularly at horrific time as this.

I'm old, too, and "back in the day" toy guns looked like toys, not like realistic guns as they have for the last decade or so. There's no reason kids need to have guns that look like the real thing - unless they are being groomed to own real guns by the NRA. If they want to play with guns, play with toys that look like toys.

Absolutely no motivation whatsoever can justify this ... I can't even put a word to it. Even terms like "atrocity" and "massacre" are too dignified. What kind of coward does something like this, and what kind of God would embrace him?

I think you're correct. That attitude seems reflected in response statements by police unions in NYC and Cleveland to the effect that the two victims died because they didn't "follow instructions." There was a similar tragedy in Santa Rosa, CA last year when 12 year old Andy Lopez was riddled with a hail of bullets when he didn't put down his toy rifle fast enough. I don't know where all this attitude starts, but it also seems prevalent on right wing talk radio.
Based on what I wonder?  Try a police drivealong or give paintball combat a try and I will bet that you have a different take on things.
For jumping out of a police vehicle with guns blazing.  Poor training, you are supposed to evaluate the situation.
I blame the police officer.
I don't think it works that way. Those who have an interest and brilliance in science will pursue it. I hope.

It is all very well to ask for funding to be increased. It is not going to happen in this age of unnecessary austerity. The reality is that, when adjusted for inflation, the funding for NIH has continuously decreased since 2003. Any increase in funding for Alzheimers is going to be at the expense of something else. Meanwhile, for several years now, a meme adopted by the scientific leadership is that the most pressing need is for high-risk, high-reward research. The relative scarcity of tangible rewards suggests that the high-risk part is certainly true. Perhaps in a more enlightened age, there would have been a brilliant graduate student somewhere, who while trying to simply understand a particular feature of brain chemistry, would have figured out the beginning of a cure to Alzheimers. Instead, that student is probably on Wall Street, trying to capitalize on the recently obtained freedom to invest bank deposits in derivatives.

I am in my 60s.  When I was young,kid--mainly boys--played games with fake guns, some of which looked real at least from a distance.  And you didn't hear reports of police shooting a kids because they were carrying, brandishing, etc., the "weapons."  On the other hand, the news media wasn't filled with stories of 12 and 13 years kids walking into their schools and shooting students and teachers, committing armed robberies, or killing people in drug violence, etc.  Unfortunately, an officer may overreact if the child is in a high crime area or appears to "threaten" others, especially if the officers are given consistent and regular training on how to assess and defuse possible dangerous situations.  Officers have a responsibility to think before acting; however, so do parents.

Zaks - I'm afraid you're simply lashing out. You appear to be the one on your high horse accusing others of "minimizing" the human cost here - when in fact what we are horrified by it and are trying to identify the reasons this happened and prevent it from EVER happening again. Getting annoyed at us is not the way forward.... we need to also be realistic and understand where this has come from. I sense self-righteousness in your reaction and a distinct lack of the ability or desire to take stock of why Pakistan has been in this state for so long.
Very well said...

Thomas Zaslavsky - It is certainly true that there is moral corruption and ethical corruption as well as legal corruption that is a crime. But in this case, the corruption is legal corruption, put into a law. I don't understand him to mean it was an immoral or unethical action, but that the law is legally corrupt.

That means favors done in return for favors, quid pro quo hidden as best they can, but still quid pro quo. That's what he said, "they've bought themselves a Congress" which is delivering what was paid for, "the worst of Washington deal making."

So who got what in return for specific actions? Investigate. Jail them. That's illegal. That's why they try to hide it.

I and the civilised countries of the world are all sick of this depraved, perverted, heartless and soul-deadened pathological human evil.  It's traumatising just to read such accounts as well as incomprehensible to explain them to others.  All people in this part of the world need to 'Change their story' as at present and with no 'reverence for life' in this and so many other parts of the world' they have no future.  I suspect and can clearly see there are other places in the world, so removed from history, thought, time, and logic as well as reality, that they just need to be sadly written off.  The "best" gift that we as adults can give the entire world at this time is to lead by and with compassion, and example.  Authentically loved and carefully protected children and citizens and thus society should be at the top of our list of exports as a template for others to emulate and improve upon.   This is like looking through a telescope in reverse and thus back to a era when life, people etc. had little or no meaning and primitive savagery ruled the earth.

Menendez is involved in other corrupt practices under investigation. I can guarantee he would not exert this kind of pressure on behalf of some economic refugee- illegal border crosser. Nor is Hilary shy in scooping up cash. What is astounding is the brazeness of the corruption. The politicians of both parties now hold the American citizen in such contempt that they do not bother to hide their actuons.
If this was your average Ecuadoran, would his extradition be held up at the highest level? These stories are great but too infrequent. It appears tonight that the governor of NC and Sanford of SC have been caught up in some financial scheme as well.

There are two sides to this conversation and both need to be heard.

Guns have the potential to kill another human being. Two years ago a student brought a similar toy gun to school that I work at with the bright orange tip taken off. The teacher who noticed it while he was unloading his backpack was rightfully scared. Part of our discussion with the student and his parent was that, had he decided to walk around the community with the gun pulled out, he may have been shot.

There needs to be a more strict protocol in how police address potential threat from a firearm, but there also needs to be recognition that a firearm can KILL someone. While police should not shoot upon first sight of a young person with a possible gun, neither should kids be running around unsupervised brandishing guns, even if they are fake.
So what's to stop someone intent on hurting people from spraypainting their real gun bright orange so as to lull onlookers into thinking it's a fake and not reporting it/running away from it?

The solution - at least partially - is to require all toy firearms to be completely covered in bright orange, while simultaneously forbidding any manufacturer or owner from using such a color scheme on a real gun.  The toy gun used in this tragic case was frighteningly realistic once its orange marker had been removed.

It was sold with the legally required International Orange muzzle, but some kid peeled it off just to make it look real and Rice paid the ultimate price.

Someone suggested that the police be willing to take a bullet as opposed to defending themselves from a very credible threat. Are you kidding? Would you step in front of a loaded gun or what seemed to be one on some sort of principal?

Do yourself and your family a favor and stay away from police work as your mindset will get you killed long before you see your pension.

The picture of that toy gun tells about 10,000 words. Doesn't justify the shooting of the young boy but my God it's scary looking, looks very real. Why is it made and who sells that kind of thing? And who lets their child play with that sort of toy?
Dumb and Dumber logic - whole point of brandishing a real [or de-oranged toy] gun is for the effect it creates...
I've got to wonder whether folks with real weapons might not paint the end of the barrel orange to give the impression they're carrying a toy gun.

I have a vivid memory of picking two dandelions for my toddler son, putting one in each of his hands, and being horrified as he immediately started pretending they were guns. Good luck with your campaign to eliminate gun play!

Yes, but how realistic are two dandelions? How would dandelions, bananas, hands (like in the article's photo) be perceived by police?  Guess gun manufacturers could start making guns in bright purple that look like cameras or blenders.
Gun play as inevitable is an assumption.  If we didn't tolerate it or glamorize guns, we would see a lot less of it.

"The truthiness will set you free!"

I think these words ring true for Stephen Colbert's character. There were moments of partial truths from Colbert's alter ego. This is what made his political commentary so useful. It made my family discuss the issue from both the conservative and liberal side. My high schoolers would carry on serious debates with my husband and I about important issues such as super-pacs, Sarah Palin, immigration, gun control and most recently ISIS.

Mr. Colbert got a generation to "watch the news" and have a great time doing so. He made us all think and open up discussions in our home that would never have taken place without his genius. I am truly grateful.
@Runaway:  "Perhaps he will get what he has always secretly wished:  he will ride off into the sunset with Mathew Mcconnahey".  Well.....put a gun to his head and he sure would!
Perhaps he will get what he has always secretly wished: he will ride off into the sunset with Mathew Mcconnahey.

BigOil: You are only looking at the price in Dollars. But there is something very strange about the simultaneous fall of oil and the Ruble against the US Dollar (USD):

Back in June 2014, oil was at $115 per barrel and the Ruble was steady at 35 Rubles per USD. (R/USD)

So for each barrel of oil, Russia was receiving 115 X 35 R/USD, or 4,025 Rubles per barrel.

Fast forward to Dec 15, 2014:

Now, oil has fallen to $55 a barrel, and we see from this article that the Ruble has fallen to 80 per USD. I saw a sign that said 85 R/ USD, but I’ll use 80.

So now, for each barrel of oil, Russia gets 55 X 80 R/USD, or 4,400 Rubles per barrel!

IF my calculator is correct, 4,400 Rubles is about 9 (nine) per cent MORE Rubles per barrel than Russia was getting 6 months ago!

Of course, that is NOT all that is going on. Still, I have to ask: “What is wrong with this picture?”

Contrast 2014 with the 1980s, when the Ruble was fixed at 6 (six) Rubles/USD. So, in 1985, when the U.S. caused the Saudis to cut oil production by 2 million Barrels Per Day, oil “tanked” from $30 to $10. (Nov. 1985 to Feb. 1986). By Dec. 1991, when the Soviet Union Collapsed, oil had only recovered to about $16.90 per barrel.

In the 1980s, the Ruble stayed at 6 R/USD, so when oil fell in USD, it fell in Rubles as well.

I believe by 1991, the Ruble at fallen to about 31 R/USD, if memory serves.

http://www.linkedin.com/in/rdelrosso2001

David: the majority of your comments indicate that you would be feeling good about Russia and Putin's place in its history if you were Czar Nicholas facing the firing squad in Yekaterinburg July 1918.

You're right but these are different times my friend. Kinds carry real guns to school sometimes. Unheard of in my day. That gun in the picture would cause almost anyone to panic from any distance. Not defending cop for the shooting, but it is a tough job.
